awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Exploring Nanocellulose Based Foams for Low-Cost, Single-Use, Biodegradable Medical Patient Support and Positioning Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project includes the ability to help the healthcare industry meet infection control and waste mitigation goals and, over the long-term, to help control costs and improve healthcare outcomes. The proposed project will develop cost-effective, single-use and fully compostable, medical grade materials capable of replacing petroleum-based polyurethane foams that are either incinerated or landfilled annually.  The project has benefits specific to the state of Maine, where the closure of six pulp and paper mills in a two-year period has been disastrous for the economic health of local communities. The team proposes the use of foams for patient positioning made from wood biomass (lignocellulose/wood residue/nanocellulose) as an important pivot for the state, creating jobs in the most rural parts of the state. This project is one example of expanding the use of the nation’s abundant biomass resources while maximizing economic, social and environmental outcomes. The proposed entrepreneurial leadership training activities will directly benefit the student participants, whose future activities will have measurable impact in these communities.

The proposed project will address a major demand in the healthcare industry for cost-effective single-use and fully compostable, medical grade materials capable of replacing tens of millions of tons of petroleum-based polyurethane foams that are either incinerated or landfilled annually. Lignocellulosic based foams are carbon positive, green alternatives to polyurethane that could replace existing materials in some positioning applications provided that certain softness/elasticity targets are achieved and that production at bulk scale can be sufficiently demonstrated. The research objectives of this project are: 1) to explore the use of “green” hydrogen-bond disrupting plasticizers and wetting agents, to achieve improved mechanical properties while maintaining compostability, and 2) to assess the feasibility of and optimize the processing conditions for the use of microwave dewatering as a more efficient and economically viable approach to produce biomass materials at an industrially meaningful physical size.  This approach to formulation could generate >200 material variants as well as corresponding mechanical assessment data. The microwave processing parameters necessary to form and dewater these materials, as well as potential heat and material transfer limitations on sample volume, will be determined. Together these data will inform the feasibility of translating this material system into practice.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The cost of medical waste in the United States is estimated to be between $760 billion and $935 billion annually, which is about 25% of the total healthcare spending.1 COVID brought about increased use of single-use disposable surgical and clinical materials believed to improve infection control but are costly to produce and dispose of.   While there are many elements required to implement a successful waste reduction program, including efficient inventory management, waste segregation and audits, perhaps the most easy to adopt for immediate impact is the purchase of more sustainable alternatives to existing medical products.  At present, there exists no universal, alternative material system capable of replacing the broad array of costly medical products being utilized by hospital systems.  

 

Our novel material system and patented production methodology is based on microwave foamed composites of inexpensive cellulosic fiber and wood residues, and naturally sourced cellulose nanofibrils (CNF).   The material is produced utilizing a patented fibrillation process. Preliminary results demonstrate the properties desired for use in a broad range of surgical and clinical positioning applications, including foam surgical positioners. Unlike current petroleum based foams, our materials are water based, can be safely composted, and make use of naturally produced forest residues. These single-use cellulosic-based medical grade foam materials could meet or exceed the requirements for a broad range of positioning applications. Our patented material system and microwave foaming production process utilizes domestically sourced advanced forest products to generate materials that are cost effective and directly address the need for high quality single-use devices which reduce the risks of infection and viral transmission.  Matching the proven and likely physical properties of this new material system with candidate applications, leading to stakeholder testable prototypes,  are critical first steps along the path to commercialization.

 

This collaborative PFI-TT project focused entirely on R&D activities, assessing candidate foam materials composed entirely of naturally sourced materials and generated using new microwave based processing techniques coupled with conventional drying approaches. Working with industry partners, target applications were identified, and realistic performance benchmarks were developed. Through simple formula modification and processing condition optimization, critical material performance benchmarks were achieved and other, desirable material features were identified and explored. These key benchmarks, utilizing current polyurethane foams as a target comparison material, were determined through collaboration with industry partners in the foam medical positioning space. Iterative prototype assessment with these partners resulted in identification of successful performance indicators as well as identified remaining and new desired and necessary characteristics guiding current and future development activities.  

 

Day-to-day activities including formula modification, material assessment, and prototype generation were carried out by a team of graduate and undergraduate engineering students at the University of Maine. As part of this PFI-TT project student participants learned key innovation and commercialization skills through a new graduate Innovation Engineering course offering. Learnings from this class were demonstrated through periodic industrial stakeholder engagement where key findings were presented, and ongoing performance characteristics were identified, iteratively driving development and prototype activities.


Last Modified: 12/03/2024
Modified by: Michael D Mason
